text: Martin Puchner is a literary critic and philosopher. He studied at Konstanz University, the University of Bologna, and the University of California, Santa Barbara, before receiving his Ph.D. at Harvard University. Until 2009 he held the H. Gordon Garbedian Chair at Columbia University, where he also served as co-chair of the Theater Ph.D. program.Columbia U English & Comparative Literature faculty profiles He now holds the Byron and Anita Wien Chair of Drama and of English and Comparative Literature at Harvard University.http://www.fas.harvard.edu/home/news-and-notices/news/press- releases/puchner-05112010.shtml He is the founding director of the Mellon School of Theater and Performance Research at Harvard University. As a literary critic, he focuses on modernism, especially such genres as the closet drama,Stage Fright: Modernism, Anti-theatricality, and Drama (Baltimore: The Johns Hopkins University Press, 2002) the literary manifesto,Poetry of the Revolution: Marx, Manifestos, and the Avant-Gardes (Princeton: Princeton University Press, 2006) and modern drama.Modern Drama: Critical Concepts (New York: Routledge, 2007) His philosophical work concerns the philosophical dialogue and the intersections of theater and philosophy.The Drama of Ideas: Platonic Provocations in Theater and Philosophy (New York: Oxford University Press, 2010) In an interview with Rain Taxi, Puchner anticipates the avant- garde in the 21st century in its relation to media, asserting “We are going through a media revolution even more extreme than that of the 20th century. I would say that an avant-garde for the 21st century would have to develop ways of using our own new media in critical, innovative, provocative ways. It would also have to be part of a political analysis of our moment, and translate that analysis into a new set of attitudes and ambitions.”Bourgeois, Louis. "Poetry of the Revolution: An Interview with Martin Puchner", Rain Taxi. Spring 2014. He is the general editor of the Norton Anthology of World Literature and lectures on world literature. In 2016 he launched a HarvardX MOOC on World Literature.https://www.edx.org/course/masterpieces-world-literature-harvardx- hum12x-0 In 2017, he won a Guggenheim Fellowship.https://www.gf.org/fellows/all-fellows/martin-puchner/ He currently is a Cullman Fellow at the New York Public Library.https://www.nypl.org/press/press-release/april-20-2017/new-york- public-librarys-dorothy-and-lewis-b-cullman-center In 2017, he published a sweeping account of literature from the invention of writing to the Internet: The Written World: The Power of Stories to Shape People, History, Civilization. New York: Random House, 2017.http://www.penguinrandomhouse.com/books/253470/the-written-world-by- martin-puchner/9780812998931/ The book won advanced praise from Margaret Atwood.https://twitter.com/MargaretAtwood/status/876266023283982336 On October 13, 2020, W. W.
